Reading List from Powerful Ideas

Thursday, January 05, 2012

Last semester I took a course titled Powerful Ideas: Useful Tools to Understand the World. It was taught by Nancy Hechinger and Alan Kay came in once a month as well as wrote us each week via email.

Throughout the class many, many books were mentioned. Way more than could be read in one semester, more even than I could manage in a year. This list is a great addendum to Alan Kay's own reading list.

  • Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain, Betty Edwards
  • Eye and Brain, Richard Gregory
  • The Victorian Internet, Tom Standage
  • A Brief History of the Organization: From The Dawn of Civilization to Leadership of Today's Corporation, Lynn Bentley
  • The Silent Language, Edward Hall
  • Einstein's Dreams, Alan Lightman
  • Mr. Tompkins in Paperback, George Gamow
  • How the Hippies Saved Physics, David Kaiser
  • McGuffey's Eclectic Reader, Williams Holmes McGuffey
  • Relativity Visualized, Lewis Carroll Epstein
  • The Electrical Experimenter, periodical
  • Scientific American, September 1966, periodical, an excerpt here
  • Disappearance of Childhood, Neil Postman
  • Gutenberg Galaxy, Marshall McLuhan
  • The Secret of Childhood, Maria Montessori
  • Character of Physical Law, Richard Feynman
  • The Inner Game of Tennis, W. Timothy Gallwey
  • The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins
  • The Children's Machine: Rethinking School in the Age of the Computer, Seymour Papert
  • Mindstorms: Children, Computers, and Powerful Ideas, Seymour Papert
